thread.title: Revealed: Top 20 richest people in East Midlands according to 2018 Sunday Times list

author: Tom Pegden
title: Revealed: Top 20 richest people in East Midlands according to 2018 Sunday Times list
text:
Rich List author: My thoughts
At number seven on the list is David Ross, Brexit supporter and co-founder of Carphone Warehouse, who owns the Nevill Holt Estate near Market Harborough.
He is one of only two people in the East Midlands Rich List who has seen a decline in wealth, reportedly down £103 million.
He helped co-found Carphone Warehouse along with Sir Charles Dunstone, who he met at Uppingham School in Rutland.
David Wilson and family - who own Ibstock-based Davidsons Developments - are reportedly worth £603 million, which is up £63 million on last year, placing them number eight in the Sunday Times list.
Sir David Samworth and family come in at number 10 with a reported wealth of £530 million - up one quarter. David Samworth at the 2016 Leicester Mercury Business Executive of the Year Awards
More than half the pork pies eaten in the UK are made by Melton-based Samworth Brothers - not to mention pasties, pies and sandwiches.
The food supply business has also just built a huge new distribution hub on Leicester Distribution Park. Who topped the list?
The overall leader of this year's East Midlands list is Mike Ashley, 53, with a fortune now put at £2.437 billion, up from £2.16 billion a year ago.
The Sports Direct business, which is based the Derbyshire/Nottinghamshire border, is worth £2.05 billion and recent windfalls from the sale of shop leases he owned on 32 stores raised nearly £87 million. Read More
The Sunday Times said the business’s recovering share price justifies raising Mr Ashley to £2.437 billion, though his wealth remains well down on the £3.75 billion he reached four years ago. 'The backgrounds of rich listers are increasingly diverse'
Robert Watts, the compiler of The Sunday Times Rich List, said: “For years manufacturing muscle, property development and housebuilding dominated wealth creation in this part of Britain. But now we’re seeing people from all walks of life amass vast fortunes.
“Our East Midlands Rich List includes vast sums made from computer games, mobile phones and even chicken farming. While we still have one aristocrat in this group, the backgrounds of rich listers are increasingly diverse.
“In Mike Ashley there is a former squash coach. John Bloor started out as a plasterer. Mel Morris left school at 16 and sold flooring before making a fortune from mobile gaming. Read More £250m of investments boost Leicestershire economy
“These rags to riches stories are one of the dominant themes of this, our 30th edition of The Sunday Times Rich List.”
The national 2018 Sunday Times Rich List will be published in a 160-page magazine with this weekend's edition of the paper. Like us on Facebook
